[seeker] But I have been in new york city all year and my parents just got me tickets to fly home [seeker] I really miss them [supporter] I am sorry to hear that but try not to panic, just failing one class is not the end of the world. How do you feel about retaking it? [seeker] I don't mind retaking it, really [supporter] Ah so you feel that this is going to be severely disruptive to your plans for this winter break? [seeker] yha. also, im worried i might fail again if i get too distracted by my family [supporter] Is it possible for you to get any sort of private tutoring which might help you? [seeker] i mean, tutoring is just another added time commitment. I really failed the first time because i was depressed and unmotivated. which is why I'm excited to be with my family finally [supporter] Ah .. in that case is it possible to talk to your doctor? They might be able to get a special allowance for you given your personal circumstances [seeker] yeah. that's another thing. I havent told my therapist or even my parents yet [seeker] that i failed [supporter] I think that it would be a really good idea if you talked to them about it. They will probably be a lot more understanding than you might think [seeker] what if they're disappointed [supporter] If they love you, and I am sure that your family do, then they will accept what has happened without criticism [seeker] how do i even begin to start the conversation [supporter] Well, do you have any siblings that you are close to and that you could tell first? [seeker] yeah i told my twin sister, actually [supporter] It is good to hear you have a twin. Are you very close? [seeker] definitely. we go to different schools but we live together in nyc [supporter] Well I think that it might be a very good idea if she could approach the rest of your family and maybe even your therapist on your behalf? [seeker] yha she's better at breaking bad news than i do... maybe i can ask her. i think i should tell my therapist myself though. [supporter] Well, your therapist is not, in my mind, as important as  your family. But I think that both will understand!
label: B
generated_reasoning:
Step 1: The seeker's underlying goal is to find emotional support and guidance on how to handle their academic failure, family concerns, and personal feelings of depression and anxiety.  
Step 2: The main strategy the supporter used is Affirmation and Reassurance, combined with providing suggestions and empathetic listening.  
Step 3: Yes, the support matched the seeker's intent and priorities by validating their feelings, offering understanding, and suggesting practical steps like talking to family and professionals.  
Step 4: The seeker gave a satisfaction score of 5 because the supporter effectively addressed their emotional needs with empathy, reassured them that they are not alone, and provided helpful, relevant advice that aligned with their concerns.

situation: I have been self-isolating since March which has made my chronic depression worse than ever. I live alone and have not touched another human being in all that time.
input:
[seeker] Things have much worse the last couple weeks [supporter] It seems like things have not be great for you over the past couple of weeks. Why do you feel they have been worse? [seeker] I had been seeing a therapist online and two weeks ago he was really mean, but said he thought it was a good session and we were making a breakthrough. Then when I signed on last week I signed in to request entrance into the meeting and after a few moments was told it was denied. Nothing like feeling the person who is paid to help you refusing to talk to you [supporter] That seems like a frustrating experience. What were your expectations of the session you were supposed to have? Did you feel like what you learned in your previous session would have helped you with dealing with what you typically work on in your mental health sessions
? [seeker] I feel like he didn't help at all. Up to that point we mostly just talked about politics or whatever. I'm a charity patient, he get's paid through the organization, but because of my financial difficulties, I'm not paying. I think he saw that as a shortcoming on my part. [supporter] I think that is definitely one way to look at it. But another way to look at your situation is you figured out a therapist who isn't worth seeing. That brings you one step closer to finding one who does actually help you. All you need to do now, is do some research and find someone who has your best interest in mind. Believe me, there are great therapists and terrible therapists. You just need to find one of the good ones now. [seeker] I'm not sure I can find another who I don't have to pay. My insurance has a $20 copay and if I had to pay that I wouldn't be able to buy groceries. This came through my religious organization and he was the only one available in my area. I guess I just have to find another way to cope [supporter] If you have financial issues and you need the help from a therapist you deserve the treatment. One thing you can do is apply for Medicaid and EBT. The state you live in will give you money to pay for groceries and to get help from a therapist for free if you don't have a high enough income. It may be worth looking into because all you really need to do is fill out some forms and likely you will be approved. When I was younger and struggling, this had happened to me and I received both of these benefits and it totally turned my life around. I think it can do the same for you as well.
label: B
generated_reasoning:
Step 1: The seeker's goal is to find effective and affordable ways to cope with their depression and improve their mental health support options.  
Step 2: The supporter primarily used Providing Suggestions and Giving Information to address the seeker's financial and therapeutic concerns.  
Step 3: The support partially aligned with the seeker's intent by offering practical solutions but did not fully acknowledge the emotional frustration and disappointment the seeker expressed.  
Step 4: The seeker gave a satisfaction score of 4 because, while the supporter provided helpful practical advice and reassurance, they may have lacked sufficient empathy for the seeker's emotional distress and unmet needs, leading to a generally positive but not entirely fulfilled experience.

situation: My child has so much homework every day and despite working for hours still is struggling every night. I'm so nervous for her and want to see her succeed.
input: [seeker] I'm so worried about my child who has so much homework and despite studying all night still is struggling. [supporter] Hello! How are you feeling today? [seeker] I'm a bit worried today and nervous. [supporter] You are a very good parent to care and worry. I get it, I am a mom myself! Is your child doing digital learning or in person? [seeker] It's actual a hybrid which is challenging.  2 days in school and 3 days at home. [supporter] I can see how that is challenging [supporter] Is it the same teacher for both? [supporter] That has to be really frusterating not having just one teacher you can go to in order to see if there is anyway to help your child not struggle [seeker] I want to push her to keep working, but also want to give her a break from all the work.  There is so much homework for a little child. [supporter] Perhaps you can find out which classes your child struggles with and contact the teacher(s) or school to set up a conference? I know some schools even have peer tutors they say help pair students with! [seeker] I'm thinking about tutoring possibly but being home and going to school it is so overwhelming already and to add tutoring to the list is another question for me. [supporter] My children are five and eight. My eight year old spent about ten hours doing digital learning the other day when in-perosn was closed. I was so frusterated. I let her pick a movie and snack when she was done to reward her for finishing. [seeker] Yes, we've had some months worth of snacks!  Good thing for Burger King! [supporter] Have you looked into any edulational or learning games? [supporter] There is nothing wrong with rewarding your child for doing good in school or getting thier work done! :) [seeker] That is a good idea.  I wonder if they have one for vocabulary as that is the test tomorrow!  She says she loves them. [seeker] I'll have to look! [supporter] I have done that with my kids. Technology is such a huge part of children's lives these days, they will play a videogame in a heart beat. I don't think they even realize they are learning sometimes! label: B

situation: My (ex)fiancé and I recently broke up, but we're still spending a great deal of time together, and we both say we're not sure if our relationship is 100% "done" and agreed to tell each other if we start dating other people. He said he doesn't want to see anyone else, but I came over one night to find him with a woman. It was their third date.
input:
[supporter] Hello, how are you doing? [seeker] Well, my fiance and I "sort of" broke up recently. I moved out of our place and all, but we continued to see each other at least 3X per week. And we both said we're not 100% sure that we're ok with us being done for good. - We promised to tell each other if we start dating anyone. He said he wasn't interested in dating. Three days after that conversation, I come over unexpectedly to find him making dinner for a woman I've never seen before. Turns out it was his 3rd date with her. He met her on a dating app a week before our conversation about promising to tell each other if we start dating others. [supporter] I'm so sorry that happened. Are you mostly hurt because he didn't tell you he was seeing somebody else? [seeker] To be honest, I'd still be hurt if he told me. But now on top of that hurt, I feel disrespected... and everything I thought I knew about him is kind of crushed. We were together 6 years, and I always, ALWAYS believed he was the most honest, kind, "stand up guy" I've  ever known. [supporter] You must feel really torn up about it. I can tell that you care about your relationship. [seeker] Yes, that's true. The worst part is that he doesn't seem to think I have a right to be hurt. How do I even deal with someone who hurt me but doesn't care to take any responsibility whatsoever? [supporter] Maybe he didn't intend to hurt you. Its not like he invited you over to tease you. It is true that he didn't keep his promise, and that's his fault. [seeker] That's true. He didn't invite me over. I expected him to be at work that night. I was coming over to see our cats, which still all lived with him. I still had a key and it didn't occur to me that I could invade his privacy since I had been spending 3X a week with him, and he was fine with me using the key. The whole thing was a shock. I wouldn't have come in had I known what I'd find inside. [supporter] That would definitely add to the distress of the situation to have a weird surprise like that. It doesn't really seem like your fault that you were there but it is unfortunate nonetheless. Have you tried talking to h
im yet? [seeker] Yeah. It's a long story to explain here, but at first he told me it was a first date... then he said it was a second date... then finally he said it was a third date. I had to figure out on my own that he met her through a dating app, which makes me feel extra icky because now I kind of feel like a stalker. (Don't worry, I didn't do anything illegal or immoral to figure this out at all. He left an easy breadcrumb trail for me to follow.... but it still feels gross that I felt compelled to research the situation because I could "feel" he was lying.) [supporter] That's ok, you have a vested interest in this person. It is natural to be interested in such things. [seeker] Yes. I'm not only invested in him. I have a SUPER close relationship with his two daughters. Some of the reason he wanted to see me after our "break up" is because he didn't want to tell his daughters that I might be out of their lives forever. He told me so much. [seeker] And I love those girls so much. [seeker] They're 13 and 16. They were 7 and 11 when I started seeing their dad. [supporter] There are a lot of therapists out there that might be able to help you navigate this. It's OK to get some outside help. [seeker] That's a good suggestion. I think individual therapy might benefit me. I could ask him if he's open to couple's counseling--even if it's over, it could help with closure. [supporter] Considering how much time you've put in to this relationship, I can tell you have a lot of feelings about all of this. [seeker] I do. I appreciate your talking the time to listen to me. Sometimes just talking about an issue can help organize one's feelings and thoughts. [supporter] Really, it is no problem. It helps to let it out sometimes, I feel that. Make sure you take care of your own needs before starting to smooth things over. [seeker] That is good advice. I haven't been eating or sleeping as well as I should since this all started. I'll work on that. --- Thank you so much for your time and help and kindness. :) I wish you a great weekend! [supporter] Thanks and you too, stay strong!
label: B
generated_reasoning:
Step 1: The seeker's goal is to find emotional support, validation, and guidance to cope with the pain and confusion caused by her breakup and her feelings of betrayal.  
Step 2: The main strategy the supporter used is Affirmation and Reassurance, along with some Reflection of Feelings.  
Step 3: Yes, the support matched the seeker's intent and priorities by validating her feelings, acknowledging her distress, and offering practical suggestions for coping.  
Step 4: The seeker gave a satisfaction score of 5 because the supporter effectively provided empathetic listening, validated her complex emotions, and offered helpful advice, making her feel heard, understood, and supported.

situation: Raising grandson and he is being very difficult and not listening.  I also have a lot of medical issues that limit my abilities.  And my grandson's father is no help, he just drops him off and leaves, never asks if need anything or how I am doing.
input:
[supporter] Hello, how are you feeling today? [seeker] Hi to be honest I am very depressed and angry today [supporter] I'm sorry to hear that. What is causing you these feelings? [seeker] Since helping to raise my grandson and his dad is not helping, or cares how I am feeling.  My grandson has been really difficult lately and I find myself losing my temper quickly
. [supporter] I'm sorry to hear that. That sounds like a difficult situation. Have you tried any personal exercises to help you cope with the situation until you find a resolution? [seeker] I do go to a quiet place and try some deep breathing, but my grandson always comes walking in [supporter] That's certainly a difficult situation. Is there no resolution possible with the father of your grandson? I want to make sure that th
e cause of the depression has properly been addressed by you or someone else. [seeker] I try talking to him, but due to my grandson having some disabilities his dad does not really want to be bothered.  I just want my grandson to succeed and be the best he can be [supporter] I think it's great that you have such care and concern for your grandson. That shows how incredible you are and on behalf of your grandson, I think you are doing a tremendous job. I think you should continue to support him however you can, but it's also important to take care of yourself. Do you have time available for additional self care, or are there any new exercises you can try to try to take care of yourself? [seeker] Thank you for saying that it means alot having someone tell me I am doing a good job. 
I recently purchased a hot tub and have been thinking that maybe when he goes to bed I could go out and relax, but have not done that yet [supporter] That sounds like a great start. Self care is vitally important in this difficulty time with COVID and the pandemic. I recommend any little bit of time that you can contribute to yourself, this includes reading, relaxing, meditating, exercise, or just resting. Anything that can help you repair so you are better prepared to help your grandson.
label: B
generated_reasoning:
Step 1: The seeker's goal is to find support and validation for their efforts to cope with depression and caregiving stress, and to feel understood and encouraged.  
Step 2: The main strategy the supporter used is Affirmation and Reassurance.  
Step 3: Yes, the support matched the seeker's intent and priorities by validating their feelings, acknowledging their efforts, and offering encouragement.  
Step 4: The seeker gave a satisfaction score of 5 because the supporter provided empathetic validation, expressed appreciation for their caregiving, and suggested practical self-care strategies, fulfilling both emotional and practical needs.
